DOC.HEAD: Store Owners Told Looting Not Covered by Insurance
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of store owners whose shops were sacked by frenzied looting after the U.S. invasion were told Wednesday that ``acts of war'' were not covered by their insurance policies. ``We regret to inform you that the claim you have submitted ... must be rejected because the insurance policy excludes losses suffered as a direct or indirect result of acts of war,'' said one letter Panamanian insurance companies were mailing Wednesday to their clients. Conservative estimates by insurance brokers and store owners put the damage and losses between $750 million and $1 billion, according to Alfredo Maduro, president of the Panamanian Chamber of Commerce. Maduro said Panamanian businessmen will now ask the United States for direct assistance to try to recover losses and resume operations. ``This is a bomb worse than the ones of last Wednesday. The insurance companies are saying that in an invaded country there is no insurance coverage,'' insurance broker Gilberto Jimenez said in an interview. Businessmen have estimated that more than 90 percent of the shops were looted on Via Espana and Central Avenue, two commercial streets in downtown Panana City. Thousands of looters raided everything from food, furniture, televisions and appliances. Only bookstores survived. Lazaro Gago, owner of the Gago supermarket chain, said six of his nine establishments had been looted and added his company was ``in ruins.'' Eight of nine of the Arrocha pharmacies also were looted. A car company said it lost $4 million to looters. Avis and other rental companies still were looking for cars taken from their lots. Television stations ran ads from car distributors offering rewards for information leading to the recovery of new vehicles. Looting damage in El Dorado, a shopping center for upper middle neighborhoods, was estimated at $25 million. Maduro said the chamber would ask for direct U.S. assistance ``in the form of equipment, technology and interest-ree loans, something like a Marshall Plan for Panama.'' ``It is our responsibility to rebuild the economy,'' Maduro said, ``but we do not have the capacity at this time.'' Both Maduro and Jimenez regretted the damage was done mostly by Panamanians. ``We have committed a grievous mistake,'' Maduro added. ``We attacked our own business establishments while the Americans were attacking military targets only.''
